section.title: Overview
section.para: The objective of this tour is to familiarize you with different sections of the Netspective Enterprise Console.

The NEF and all application components built with it can be viewed with the Netspective Enterprise Console servlet. The Console is a Sparx servlet that provides a browser-based administrative interface to all of the dynamic Netspective Enterprise Frameworks Suite (NEFS) components and objects associated with your application.
The Console is an optional component for every application built with NEF and it is turned on by default. You may decide to turn it off completely for your applications or secure it differently.

section.title: Accessing the Console in Applications
section.para: Each application has a private instance of the Console using the http://server/appName/console pattern. When you log into the Console for Application X (appX/console) versus Y (appY/console) you will only see components for the appropriate application.
Here are some examples of how to access the Console for some of the sample applications.

listitem.para: The Sampler App demonstrates various elements of NEFS. Its application identifier is nefs-sampler. The URL for Sampler App is http://www.netspective.com/nefs-sampler and its Console URL is http://www.netspective.com/nefs-sampler/console. Note that the Console is accessed simply by adding the /console path at the end of the application's URL

The Books sample application is the sample application that demonstrates how to create a database application and its application identifier is nefs-sample-books. The URL for Books App is http://www.netspective.com/nefs-sample-books and its Console URL is http://www.netspective.com/nefs-sample-books/console. Note that the Console is accessed simply by adding the /console path at the end of the application's URL.

When writing your own application you will simply append /console to the end of your own application's context identifier. If your app is available at http://your-server/your-app-id then the Console for your application would be available at http://your-server/your-app-id/console.

section.title: Login to Enterprise Console
section.para: The Console's default user name is 'console' and the default password is 'console' (each without quotes) . Unless otherwise specified, that is the user name and password combination you should use if the Console prompts you to login.
To save your Console User ID on the computer, select the checkbox provided with Remember my ID on this computer option.

section.title: Console Home
section.para: When you successfully login to the Console, it displays the Console Home.
The Console Home displays the following information:

listitem.para: This is the welcome message giving a summary about Console usage.

The Configuration Overview provides configuration details for the application. The application ID refers to the application identifier for the application with which the Console is associated (nefs-sample-books in this case). The Application Home provides the physical path where the application resides. The Sparx Project Source provides the link to the project.xml file for your application. You may view the project.xml file by clicking on this link. The Runtime Environment tells you if the application is working under development environment or the production environment. A link is provided to the web.xml file containing the deployment information for your application. You may view the web.xml file by clicking on this link.
This section details the versions info for various application components. For example, JDK, JVM and App Server versions.
This section provides information about different methods through which you can set the Console security option.

section.title: Sitemap
section.para: Click on the Home | Sitemap submenu to view the complete sitemap for the Console application. You may use this sitemap to navigate through various Console sections.

section.title: Project
section.para: The Project section provides you access to various aspects of your project. This includes the project source files, the Ant build scripts and Access Control options. In addition to this, this section provides the documentation for the Commands and Value sources provided by NEFS. You may also access the project matrices from this section.

section.title: Source
section.para: All of the NEF (Sparx, Axiom, and Commons) components are declared in an input source file known as the Project File. Click the Project | Source menu item to view the information about your application's project source file.

You can view the link to the active project source file. By clicking on this link, you can open the project file for view. The default Project File is APP_ROOT/WEB-INF/sparx/project.xml but may be configured to be a different file.

section.title: Viewing project dependencies
section.para: You can also see all the included resources, components, and files (all of the final paths of any <xdm:include> tags). The number of dependencies is displayed, within parantheses, with the project file link. The details of the dependent files is also provided.

section.title: Errors and Warnings
section.para: Because the NEF manages literally hundreds of objects and classes and allows you to use XML to declare some sophisticated object relationships, many errors and warnings may be displayed. Errors are always highlighted within the Console under Errors or Warnings.

Notice that if there are any errors and you are viewing the Console you will see an error highlight at the top of the Console window. Once you're in the Console Project -> Source menu you will be presented with a listing of the errors in the middle of the page.

section.title: Specifying a different location for project source file
section.para: The Source section also displays the information about how to specify a location, other than the default location, for the project source file. You may set the location of project file in your web.xml The sample code that performs this function is also provided.

section.title: Ant Build
section.para: NEF provides a series of scripts that, among other functions, allow you to compile your application, generate code, and upgrade NEF libraries and components. All of the scripts are built to be executed in the the industry-standard Apache Ant tool. Apache Ant is included in the NEF distribution.
